item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: Clever enough, but I can't ever seem to quite "get" it.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
Age of Steam Expansion #1: England & Ireland
item.comment: Rating based only on the Ireland board. This board is somewhat imbalanced, with building first, second, and third on the first turn being much, much more important than with the regular board.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion #2: Western US and Germany
item.comment: Both solid maps, plenty of fun!

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion #4: France and Italy
item.comment: Rating Italy only. I don't think AoS needs a direct conflict mechanism and is in fact hurt by it.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: 1830's Pennsylvania / Northern California
item.comment: Rating Pennsylvania only, played with 4. It just didn't work well, as there seemed to be no viable strategy but to move a lot of black cubes, and there's no way 4 people can be over there at the same time, at least that I could see, especially with the one-link limit when building black cities. Looking forward to NoCal, though, and willing to retry this one.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Alhambra: The City Gates
item.comment: The camps, while a neat idea, clog up the tile selection too much, with some encampments -- especially the expensive ones -- blocking a color for many turns in a row. The gates are pretty nifty, and the character cards add some interesting things, though they'd be terribly imbalanced if they weren't auctioned.

item.name: Alhambra: The Vizier's Favor
item.comment: Solid improvements in the game, lots of fun.

item.name: Amazing Space Venture
item.comment: Graphically it's VERY attractive. Gameplay leaves a lot to be desire, mostly due to unnecessary complexity in the cards: too many "neat ideas" that make the game much harder to learn than it needs to be. Some "take that" is fun, but some of the "take that" cards are too powerful (e.g. destroy a planet and the ship on it, take a planet that's being built) while others are too weak (e.g. the "-1" life form and atmosphere cards), at least in comparison.

item.name: Anno 1503
item.comment: Underwhelming. Really, truly multiplayer solitaire (with only a tiny bit of exception), and unfortunately the solitaire game isn't very fun, either. Kind of Settlers meets Entdecker, but not really in a good way.

item.name: Armadöra
item.comment: Some actual graphic design and decent production design would make this feel less abstract, though it's still very much that dots-on-paper game I played as a kid.

item.name: Bacchus' Banquet
item.comment:
Once the group figures out your role, you can easily end up sitting out the entire game. If you're not forced to just sit there while everyone else plays, you'll instead be forced out of the game, where at least you can go do something else. Very disappointing.
Those who say it's rethemed Bang are completely missing the above point. At least in Bang I get to keep playing, keep trying to influence the outcome of the game. Heck, my side can even win in Bang, even if I'm knocked out.
Torturous, not at all recommended, even for those who generally enjoy "take that" games.

item.name: Bean Trader
item.comment: Nifty mechanisms but awkward play mars the game.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
Boomtown
item.comment: Very solid, lots of fun, would happily play again. Luck, while a factor, seems to play less of a role here than in other Bruno games, which is great!

item.name: Brass
item.comment: Solid and enjoyable, I look forward to working out how possible it is to focus on a given strategy rather than having to play mostly tactically.

item.name: Captain's Wager
item.comment:
With three players it is utterly, completely, and frustratingly annoying random. The winner happened to draw both 20s in the first adventure, then high cards or items that made their cards higher the rest of the game. At the end that player won every single adventure, entirely unrelated to how anyone could have played.
Beautiful art and great theme, though.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: Some clever mechanics but I just can't find the fun after several plays.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
Coloretto
item.comment: Light and fun but rich enough to still be a challenge. Good fun.

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: Light, interesting enough for me to play again, but not interesting enough to ever request it. I was hoping that the theme would be more than just tacked on (lightly, with thumbtacks and the back of a wooden spoon).

item.name: Confucius
item.comment: Two plays, both quite fun (despite getting endgame rules wrong in the first playing of the production prototype). The gift system is a very clever, truly unique mechanism that is a lot of fun.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Dilbert: Corporate Shuffle
item.comment: The less-fun version of Dalmuhti, which is the more-fun version of Asshole.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
Expedition
item.comment: Reasonable game, though it just didn't thrill me. While the photos of the locations and artifacts are nifty, an alternate graphic design would make the game quite a bit easier to play.

item.name: Fantasy Pub
item.comment: Cute and clever game. The components are quite flimsy and fairly fiddly (physically): thicker pieces and somewhat improved artwork would give it another point.

item.name: Fish Eat Fish
item.comment: I don't mind simplicity -- I love Coloretto, for example, which is quite simple -- but not at the cost of depth. Great components but a very disappointing game. (Played with 3.)

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: Played 6 of 10 rounds, will need another couple of full plays to form a full opinion.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
Gamer Tycoon
item.comment: Utterly broken, no fun at all. The concept is fun but the mechanics simply don't work, and as Rob mentioned, the rules don't even match the cards. Very, very bad.

item.name: Giganten
item.comment: Fun to play, some great opportunities for cleverness. A bit too much luck for my taste, however.

item.name: Gisborne: Die ersten Kartographen
item.comment: Didn't care for this at all. Simplistic and not much fun. Very significant runaway leader problem, surprising that it wasn't caught or addressed during design/development.

item.name: Das Gold der Maya
item.comment: Very unpleasant system for distributing your winning rocks. Game could be considerably improved by evenly dividing the winning bid among the tied losers, with extras left over for the next division. Even then, though, I'd probably only move my rating up one point. Just not enough there to be much fun, either with gamers or families.

item.name: Gulo Gulo
item.comment: Absolutely outstanding when playing with kids (as young as 3 or 4) and adults together -- a surprisingly even playing field. Nothing spectacular for just adults.

item.name: Hamsterrolle
item.comment: Great fun, certainly my favorite "physical" game (doesn't require that much dexterity).

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro
Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: Clever enough highly-abstract game. First-to-Last-then-Last-to-First (like the beginning of Settlers) seems to be a much better way to place your initial penguins (rather than the rules-suggested round and round).

item.name: Hoity Toity
item.comment: Bumped up a point as it plays very, very will with six.

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
In the Year of the Dragon
Industria
item.comment: Played it with both 3 and 4, but it doesn't really work with 3

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Rating after one play. I think I've gotten out of it all that there is to get, and future playings will likely reduce my rating, but I hope I'm wrong and there are some fun strategy options I've yet to discover.

item.name: Knights
item.comment: Much better than Yahtzee, anyway! Still, too much of a "if you don't bash the leader you won't win" factor.

item.name: Kogge
item.comment: Just didn't work for me: I couldn't find the fun. A lot of chaos made it difficult to plan much. I didn't mind the components, though.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Lifeboats
item.comment: Very bloody!

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Lost Valley
item.comment: Certainly playable, but no great shakes.

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Mall World
item.comment: Very enjoyable, if a bit abstract for my tastes. It was certainly a bit daunting and confusing at first, but it became more and more exciting as we began to understand some of the implications and how to work to get someone else to do precisely what you want done without them finding out for several turns. :)

item.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
Masterpiece
item.comment: A really great game in 1970, I had a hoot playing it as a kid -- certainly my first auction game. I'd play it again just to see the artwork (and to figure out if I could come up with an alternate set of rules to "Germanize" it with its existing components).

item.name: Mission Command Air
item.comment: Cute little game, certainly worth the $4.99 I paid for it on sale, but it's just too random for my tastes... it's as though I have no control over the speed. "I'm banking right, easing back on the throttle... no, wait, apparently I'm moving to full throttle. Huh."

item.name: Mykerinos
item.comment: Playable, certainly, and plenty quick, but not a lot of fun for me. Maybe after a second play.

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: As the English rules are written, this game is shockingly random. Might as well pull numbered chits from a bag and call the player with the highest total the winner. Stunningly bad.

item.name: Oasis
item.comment: Very solid Moon & Weissblum design. While it has some slight similarities to their others, it's really its own game and is quite fun. I look forward to trying a variant where you can preview the top face-down card, to see if perhaps it will reduce the luck just enough without adding too much analysis paralysis.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: By far my favorite cooperative game, but as with all cooperatives, the people you play with matter more than anything else.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
Power Grid
item.comment: Still my highest-rated game, both in the original edition and the remake. When played with a group of players who really know how to play this game, it's incredibly competitive and tons of fun. When played with some folks who don't know "how to play well" there can be a runaway leader problem sometimes (depending on the power plants that come up). Aweseome game, amazing fun.

item.name: Power Grid: China/Korea
item.comment: Enjoy both Korea and China. The latter is truly a great map, completely reinvigorating the game for people who love it already.

item.name: The Prestel New York Architecture Game
Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: Four plays now. Great fun with plenty of strategy, but it's a shame that you pretty much have to go for a military strategy, and the power imbalance in the families.

item.name: Railroad Dice
item.comment: Pretty sure we _finally_ played it correctly, so my rating is more meaningful. The endgame is so very different from the early game that it almost feels like you've started something else entirely.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
San Marco
item.comment: But only with 3

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: Enjoyed it the first few playings, but my pleasure has diminished with time. Perhaps it's just the group I play it with, but moves are becoming a bit too "obvious."

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: A lot of fun! Even though it was somewhat long, it was always interesting. Rating may change after my one play.

item.name: Secrets of the Tombs
item.comment: Surprisingly shallow game, not much fun.

item.name: The Settlers of the Stone Age
Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
Songburst: 70's & 80's Edition
item.comment: A not-unpleasant party game. An independent DJ is _very_ important, however.

item.name: La Strada
item.comment: Too abstract for my tastes, and the last player in a 4-player game has a substantial disadavantage (and should probably move first). I don't mind light connection games -- I'd play TransAmerica over this any day -- but it just didn't click with me.

item.name: Strange Synergy
item.comment: A light chaotic romp. Unquestionably unbalanced but still fun. If you like other Steve Jackson games you'll like this, and if you hate other Steve Jackson games you'll probably hate this one less than most of the others. The biggest "I don't like Steve Jackson games because..." item they removed was the "bash the leader just before he wins" issue that pretty much cripples games like Munchkin (where a 45 minute romp is transformed into a 3 hour dullfest). Certainly the best superhero boardgame I've ever played (maybe the only), and the potentially interesting combination of powers make it a surprisingly fun beer-n-pretzels game with excellent replay value if you like it.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: Very enjoyable, following a nice string of good games by Wallace. Very fun.

item.name: Tanz der Hornochsen!
item.comment: We played with 8, which was awfully random. I look forward to trying it with a few less (though due to its heritage, I'll be ok with some randomness).

item.name: The Testimony of Jacob Hollow
item.comment: Too much luck... you can easily be three times the player of all of your opponents combined and still lose by a large margin.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
Ticket to Ride: Mystery Train Expansion
item.comment: Rating after only one play with the expansion. In this playing I managed to blow the other players away with two Engineer cards, because at that point I already had set up a coast-to-coast route and was able to draw 40 points in specific, ideal tickets... in a sense a rich-get-richer effect. However I'm certainly going to try it again.

item.name: Time's Up! Deluxe
item.comment: By far my favorite party game. Greatness in a small box.

item.name: Tongiaki
item.comment: Updated rating after having played with 3, 4, 5, and 6 players.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment: Certainly fun enough, I'm always willing to play, but not something I'd request. I don't feel like I have enough control over the results.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
Die Weinhändler
item.comment: Interesting, clever. I'd certainly be willing to play it from time to time, but there's not enough depth for the time it takes.

item.name: Werewolf
item.comment: With a good group of players and a good moderator, there's no more fun game to be found.

item.name: Würfel Bingo
item.comment: Played with 7 players (2 sets). Surprisingly fun and clever for what seems... well, slightly lame at first. Happy to play again.
